author: @zrebbesh
text: On reinforcement learning, you can score every frame!  You need a technique called adversarial learning:  Have one network make estimates of how much progress charles can make toward the next waypoint during the next frame.  Charles can train this, rapidly, as a never-ending source of training data.  Then start counting it as an error to correct via negative reinforcement whenever charles goes slower than the estimate. And this can train Charles, rapidly, as a never-ending source of feedback.

author: @krembananowy
text: Sentdex, for the reinforcement learning the time for travel between checkpoints is the ONLY score Charles gets? If so, you are dealing with big *reward delay*. You can do something called "reward shaping" : add secondary factors to his reward. For example, if Charles arrives to a checkpoint he gets 1000 / time_taken points, but outside of that he always gets 0.1 * distance_traversed_along_gps + 0.01 * current_speed. Even if the secondary goals are purely heuristic (high speed is not always the best thing to achieve) it can push learning forward (or sideways) significantly. There is even a paper written by some students, where a Convnet was learning to play a couple of SNES games. On the racing game F-Zero the net failed to learn to make a single lap, because the points were given in form of time per lap, so only upon finishing the lap. Once they added forward velocity to the reward function and restarted the learning process they got good results really quickly.

I plan on using the TensorFlow object detection api for training. It's new and tough, but there is a few guides out there for help, I have been referencing to. As an example, if it detects a red light its stops,  green it goes, stop sign and it stops but continues after 3 seconds, etc.

author: @Carbon2251
text: Image Charles is about to hit a wall. To avoid it he has to turn left or right. So the network output could be left: 0.8,  right: 0.8. He knows he has to turn but it doesn't matter which way. With your algorithm he would go straight because the values would cancel each other out. If you did max([left, right]) it would return the biggest value so even if they are almost the same he would still turn 80% and avoid the wall. What do you think?

author: @Superpolynom
text: So „memory“ means additional outputs, which will be additional future inputs?! Currently there are four outputs (WASD), right?  Based on those assumptions: How many additional outputs would you use for a memory? How much do these additional inputs/outputs enlarge the entire network?  Would these outputs be an input for the next frame? Or can there be a delay? If so, could Charles decide how much delay is necessary?  Would it be beneficial (in terms of quality and/or performance) if only certain areas of the screen (like the map) were in higher resolution than the rest?
